body: Thanks for the patch. LGTM
cc @ijuma as well

I prefer the method taking a Range personally (it is why I suggested that offline when the discussion was taking place). It is easy to add convenience methods later, if necessary, but hard to remove methods from the interface.
@ewasserman : KAFKA-3163 is now committed. Could you rebase?
@ijuma @hachikuji FYI: I re-triggered jenkins job 5144 - 5150 on https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/ to test `testRegexMatchesTopicsAWhenDeleted`.
Since this PR introduces a new config, does it need a KIP?
LGTM over all. Just on clarification question.
Waiting for consecutive jenkins builds on https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1762 now.

@tcrayford : Thanks for the new patch. The jenkins job shows the following unit test failure, which seems is related to this patch.

kafka.log.CleanerTest > testBuildPartialOffsetMap FAILED
    java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: requirement failed: offset map is too small to fit in even a single message, so log cleaning will never make progress. You can increase log.cleaner.dedupe.buffer.size or decrease log.cleaner.threads
        at scala.Predef$.require(Predef.scala:233)
        at kafka.log.Cleaner.<init>(LogCleaner.scala:314)
        at kafka.log.CleanerTest.makeCleaner(CleanerTest.scala:530)
        at kafka.log.CleanerTest.testBuildPartialOffsetMap(CleanerTest.scala:494)

Also, when you submit a new patch, if you can preserve the commit history, it will be easier to review the delta changes.

I briefly thought about that and know that configurations are listed in the KIP "major change" section - I feel that if we are changing an existing config we definitely need to. However, for adding such a config that defaults to the existing behavior - I think we can use reasonable judgment. For this specific config I felt it is small enough to not require a KIP that I didn't even bring it up :)

If you strongly feel we need a KIP for this then we can definitely do that and back out changes if necessary.
ok, LGTM then :) Thank you for finding and fixing!

I don't feel strongly personally, just good to have a shared understanding of when we need a KIP and when we don't. In a sense, one could claim that it's a bug that we forgot to expose this particular config (we seem to expose every other JDK config).

For this particular issue, the aspect that I am not sure we explored fully is if we should change the default. As you said in your comment, even if SHA1PRNG is not supported in every platform, we can fallback if that is the case.

Perfect, thank you :)
LGTM.

wrt setting SHA1PRNG as the default, the concern that Todd raised above was if SHA1PRNG is ever considered to be insecure then we will continue to force that default on all users (while the JRE presumably translates the current default - null - to whatever is considered safe by the JRE). (How do we link to earlier comments? I just added a reaction to flag Todd's comment further above.)

I had put this in the PR above, but since it took an offline talk to make myself clear, I'll rephrase.

My concern is that if a vulnerability is discovered in SHA1PRNG, Kafka users may not realize it affects them. Since the default for the JRE is not SHA1PRNG, any communication about the vulnerability will state it's not the default implementation. Kafka users who have not changed Kafka's default may not realize that they are vulnerable because they didn't not change a default themselves. This will put the onus on us to make a change, push a bugfix, and update users.

In addition, it may not be as simple as a bugfix. If we can't use SHA1PRNG, and there is no other globally available implementation, our choices are to either add a lot of logic to select several different implementations (which is a lot of complexity and testing/performance issues), or to revert to the default behavior (which will be a severe performance regression). I feel that given all of this, it's better to retain the default behavior and explicitly call out in the documentation the performance concerns.

@toddpalino My bad, I missed your previous explanation. Thanks for reiterating. A couple of things:
1. Unsafe ciphers and algorithms are disabled by the JRE/JDK regularly. There is even a roadmap: http://www.java.com/en/jre-jdk-cryptoroadmap.html. So I think that weakens that part of the argument.
2. My concern is that people will miss the relevant paragraph in the documentation (the security docs are quite long) and leave a lot of performance on the table.

Having said that, I share your concern that an automatic fallback may lead to unexpected performance regressions if SHA1PRNG is unavailable. Given that, maybe we can leave things as they are, watch out for user feedback and re-evaluate then.
@vahidhashemian Thanks for the review. I'll check whether there's a reliable way to unit test this.
LGTM

@ijuma could you review this PR?
Thanks!

I am not sure about this change. Though the code change is small the impact to the Authorizer and what users may expect is pretty large. 

After reading the Jira in a bit more detail it looks like there is a discrepancy between removing a permission/ACL and removing access. When you grant access on a specific host with one ACL and then try to delete that access with a different (more broad) ACL, nothing changes. This may appear like the incorrect behavior but I don't think it is. Instead of changing the code to delete all matching ACLs, I think the script could likely be improved to let the user know that no ACL was deleted because the requested ACL to be deleted does not exist. Alternatively providing a mechanism to list the ACLs that match is another option but would require changes to the Authorizer interface. 

I think there are many more cases where deleting matching ACLs could cause unwanted and surprising behavior than there are ones that would cause preferable behavior. 

As a quick example, suppose you add an ACL so userA can read topic1 then by accident you add an ACL so that userA can read all(*) topics. How do you delete the second grant without deleting the first intended one?

I think this change means there is no way to delete an ACL the grants the all operation on all hosts to all principles without also deleting all defined allow ACLs.

It seems like a common problem to perform flexible and schema-agnostic aggregation from CDC source like kafka-connect.

Thanks in advance.
I've changed the cleanup.policy to take a list of values. @guozhangwang @junrao please take a look.

This is a small change to the broker to fix the specific issue reported in the JIRA where broker restarts are necessary to handle consumer rebalance when the clock is moved backwards by a significant amount. Note that this PR does not address the dependency on wall-clock time in Java clients. I have run manual tests on Linux and Mac to ensure that the issue reported in the JIRA is fixed by this PR. Also ran benchmark tests of the system test runs to compare the results with and without the PR, and comparing the results over a couple of runs, there is no noticeable impact beyond the differences between test runs. The results with the PR are https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/501/ and the results of the same trunk level without the PR are https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/500/.
Any chance to get this merge or is it not needed ?

@junrao thanks. I can certainly preserve commit history, no problem. When I was working on https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1598 I always amended, but was unsure about project conventions here. Is the usual pattern to squash on merging into trunk? I don't think the project history deserves commits like "fix code review feedback" or "fix tests" etc.

The test failure is now fixed.
@junrao Thanks a lot for the patient review. I will submit a follow up PR soon. And yes, I will start working on the KIP to add seekToTimestamp() API now and post the wiki this week.

FYI. When commit PRs to Kafka trunk, our merge tool will automatically squash all commits into a single one.

LGTM. Thanks @rajinisivaram!

@guozhangwang it's worth noting that this test never failed in Confluent Jenkins (as far as I could see), only Apache Jenkins. Apache Jenkins runs the tests with fork=1 while Confluent uses a higher fork count. Usually this makes Apache Jenkins more stable, but it may be having the opposite effect in this case (or there's another reason why the test fails in Apache Jenkins). If you want to be confident that this change fixes the issue, we'd want to run it in Apache Jenkins.
ResetIntegrationTest.testReprocessingFromScratchAfterReset is a known failure and unrelated, merged to trunk.

@becketqin, it would be good to update the Kafka documentation to mention the time index. Maybe an easy way is to search it for offset index and see if it makes sense to mention the time index in those cases as well. Would you be willing to file a JIRA and take this on as well?

This failure became quite rare at some point, last failure in trunk jdk7 build was a while back. Since this PR seems like an improvement anyway, LGTM (assuming the tests pass). If the test fails again, we can reopen the JIRA.
Thanks for the PR, LGTM.
LGTM and merged to trunk.

> I don't specify producer-props or producer-config, but I assume one is mandatory? Shouldn't we check and give proper error?

I was relegating the check to ConfigDef, however I think it is better to fail fast. Updated patch to check for it.

> What if I specify both? It looks like producer-props overrides producer-config, did we validate that this is the case? perhaps we want to make sure the built-in help includes this clarification.

Yes, producer-props will take precedence, this is in accordance with other CLI tools. Added a note about this in built-in help. Thanks for pointing this out.
Transient failure in Jenkins is not relevant; created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4075 for it.

Invalid dates seem fishy, and frankly unrelated to this particular patch unless an important date sneaks in there somewhere that doesn't like the different timezones. I am thinking maybe this has to do with the AWS VMs defaulting to UTC (which I think they do) and most dev boxes defaulting to whatever their locale is (shortened snippet from my local setup):

```
✔ ~/kafka.git [rajinisivaram-KAFKA-3799 ↑·38|✚ 1…1185⚑ 112]
20:11 $ date
Mon Aug 22 20:11:13 PDT 2016
✔ ~/kafka.git [rajinisivaram-KAFKA-3799 ↑·38|✚ 1…1185⚑ 112]
20:11 $ vagrant ssh worker1
vagrant@worker1:~$ date
Tue Aug 23 03:09:33 UTC 2016
```

The test generally looks ok to me, but I worry about these types of issues -- they are both test gaps and if we don't continue to make sure tests work on local VirtualBox VMs it makes it more difficult to develop and debug tests.
LGTM. org.apache.kafka.streams.integration.ResetIntegrationTest.testReprocessingFromScratchAfterReset refuses to pass, but it looks like it's a bug on trunk as well and unrelated...
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
Comments addressed. Thanks @junrao

@ewencp I think the issue is with clock skew since certificates are created on the host and then copied to VMs. If the host clock is behind the VM clock, tests can fail. Have opened KAFKA-4077 to fix this.
Thanks for the PR, LGTM.
The tricky thing is maintaining source and binary compatibility. Code calling this class from Java would break after your change.
No worries, I'll close the PR and JIRA
Tests passed locally, merged to trunk.
Review by @ewencp
@ijuma: Thanks for the improvements and help. Please have a look again when jenkins is done.

+1 LGTM. I tested on a few versions of Gradle 2.x to make sure it was backwards compatible too. 

Removing `useAnt = false` wont change any behavior since it was change to false by default since 2.12. [(release notes)](https://docs.gradle.org/2.12/release-notes?_ga=1.172904483.1612453537.1415050143#ant-based-scala-compiler-deprecation). Builds before 2.12 still work but result in ant output.

As a side note, what are your thoughts on removing the checked in gradlew and gradle.bat? I know it has come up in the past but still hangs around. Downloading the wrapper replaces these anyway and they cant be used until the wrapper is downloaded. It seams they are confusing to have checked in, result in arbitrary changes, and at worst could cause some gradle compatibility problem at some point. 

> It turns out that one cannot even run gradle to download the project Gradle version if useAnt is used in the build.

Yeah this is an unfortunate gradle behavior that has bit me before. Incompatible or broken scripts prevent the wrapper task from downloading a compatible version. I am not sure the best way to fix it, or if its worth fixing.

Thanks for the review @granthenke.

To be honest, I am not sure why we have checked in `gradlew`. Do you know? I think someone submitted a PR for removing those files, but I haven't reviewed it since I am missing the background for why things are as they are.

@ijuma I can look back for the history. I think what happend is all of gradle was checked in, then based on Apache policy the executables were removed. The scripts were left behind assuming they were useful. But because the gradle wrapper task needs to be called to download the executables anyway they really aren't.
Thanks for the PR, LGTM.
Thank you for considering the option to take a list. Since we now take a list, the title of the PR likely needs a change.
Interestingly, the build passed, but the test results were not found so Jenkins considered it failed. A potential change in behaviour with regards to tests.
